flags.evidence:
The manuscript states the analysis uses ACS PUMS 2011–2019 and explicitly excludes post-2019 due to COVID-19 disruptions. However, the data-fetch script downloads 2011–2022. Unless later scripts drop 2020–2022 (they do not appear to), the estimation sample in code will include 2020–2022, contradicting the paper’s stated sample period and potentially altering results.: # Fetch data for years 2011-2022
years <- 2011:2022

The cleaning/analysis dataset is filtered only by age, not by survey year. Given 01_fetch_data.R pulls 2011–2022, this script will carry 2020–2022 into analysis, conflicting with the manuscript’s claimed 2011–2019 restriction.: analysis_data <- clean_data %>%
  filter(
    !is.na(AGEP),           # Valid age
    AGEP >= 22 & AGEP <= 30  # Age range for analysis
  ) %>%

The manuscript’s tables describe weighted means and inference consistent with the discrete-RDD discussion (clustering at age). The code’s “simple mean comparison” reports weighted means but computes an unweighted, unclustered t-test (and not using survey weights). This can materially change p-values and stars in the paper’s “Panel A” style comparisons if those were derived from this function.: # T-test for difference
  t_result <- t.test(
    age_26[[outcome_var]],
    age_25[[outcome_var]]
  )

Medicaid expansion-state classification is hard-coded as a fixed list (presumably “expanded by 2014”). This is not inherently problematic, but it is a hard-coded classification that should be documented/cited (and ideally versioned by year, since expansion timing differs across states).: expansion_states <- c(4, 5, 6, 8, 9, 10, 15, 17, 19, 21,
                      24, 25, 26, 27, 32, 33, 34, 35, 36, 38,
                      39, 41, 44, 50, 53, 54, 11)

summary.executive_summary: The data retrieval script (`01_fetch_data.R`) downloads ACS PUMS microdata for 2011–2022, even though the manuscript states the analysis is limited to 2011–2019 and excludes post-2019 years due to COVID-19 disruptions. The downstream cleaning step (`02_clean_data.R`) filters only by age and does not restrict survey year, so 2020–2022 observations would remain in the analysis dataset unless excluded elsewhere, directly contradicting the stated methodology.
